author: JuliaRegistrator

comments.body:
Your `new package` pull request met all of the guidelines for auto-merging and is scheduled to be merged when the mandatory waiting period (3 days) has elapsed.

Since you are registering a new package, please make sure that you have read the package naming guidelines: https://pkgdocs.julialang.org/v1/creating-packages/#Package-naming-guidelines



---
If you want to prevent this pull request from being auto-merged, simply leave a comment. If you want to post a comment without blocking auto-merging, you must include the text `[noblock]` in your comment. You can edit blocking comments, adding `[noblock]` to them in order to unblock auto-merging.
<!-- [noblock] -->
<!---
this_is_the_single_automerge_comment
--->

I apologize for my limited knowledge in resolving this situation. 
My main branch currently contains the code of version 0.2.1 and is tagged with versions 0.1.0 and 0.2.0. 
To release v0.1.0, should I revert the main branch back to version 0.1.0, delete the 0.2.0 tag, and then reinvoke the registrator ?

Now that https://github.com/JuliaRegistries/General/pull/102993 is merged you can go ahead and try making new releases. Note that you shouldnâ€™t be creating git tags manually: Tagbots should do that for you automatically *after* a new release is merged into the registry.

My recommendation would be to delete your existing 2.0 tag, and then set the version for your current `main` brach (which you were going to release as 0.2.1) to 0.2, and then trigger the registration bot for that in order to make a 0.2 release.
